metadata.sermon_title: What a Difference a Week Makes!
metadata.sermon_start_end: A week is a long time. The week from Christmas to the next Sunday is a very long time, filled with tension, exhaustion, and extra business. [...] A new beginning wrought only by God’s overplus of power and love. A new beginning that persists in vulnerable but resilient ways.
metadata.liturgical_context: First Sunday after Christmas / Epiphany season
metadata.historical_context: Late 20th/Early 21st century North American academic/university setting. Context of social-political awareness and critique of institutional power.
metadata.notes: The sermon exhibits the characteristic 'prophetic-imagination' style of Brueggemann, focusing on the subversion of empire.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon utilizes effective, contrasting imagery to bridge the gap between the 'romantic' Christmas scene and the 'cold-faced' reality of Herod's violence. The preacher successfully 'paints the picture' by contrasting the extra sheep and oxen of the crèche with the 'furious rage' and 'biting snakes' of the subsequent week. There is a strong sense of 'showing' the transformation of characters—specifically the angels from 'sweet-voiced messengers' to 'risk-taking political actors.' While the imagery is grounded in the biblical text, it is revitalized through contemporary metaphors like the 'wild card in the deck' and 'quantifying analysis.' The sensory appeal is primarily visual and kinetic, focusing on movement (running, fleeing, returning) and the visceral threat of power.
quotes: The story overflows with wonder and amazement. For an instant, our trains stop running, we stop running...
The church would like to skip over the evil, for the church prefers to stay romantic.
The angel is the wild card in the deck of God’s history that makes all the other characters sit up and take notice.
strengths: Strong use of contrast between 'innocence' and 'brutality'.
Effective re-characterization of the angels as political agents.
Avoidance of 'dead' metaphors by placing biblical images in a modern socio-political frame.
improvement_points: Increase sensory detail regarding the 'slaughter of the innocents' to heighten the aesthetic weight of the 'trouble'.
More concrete imagery for the 'newness' mentioned in the conclusion.
Incorporate more auditory or tactile imagery to balance the visual dominance.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: The sermon leans toward 'showing' the characters' shifts, though it 'tells' the theological implications (e.g., 'Jesus is himself vulnerable') quite directly.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: The language is precise and avoids the 'Canaanite' jargon often found in Reformed preaching. Instead of using abstract terms like 'total depravity,' the preacher speaks of 'passionate rage when their interest is jeopardized.' There is a clear stewardship of language in how the preacher defines the 'overplus of God's power.' The word choice is deliberate, using terms like 'ruse,' 'credulity,' and 'maudlin' to challenge the intellectual environment of a university campus. The precision lies in the naming of human resistance to grace, describing it as 'seeking self-sufficiency' and 'imagining he can control his life.' The sentence structure is disciplined, with a rhythmic economy that makes every word count toward the larger argument.
quotes: We suspend our cynical judgment and are glad to be bathed in this narrative of innocence.
Mild people can be transformed toward passionate rage when their life is disrupted, when their interest is jeopardized...
It is an odd and awkward assignment to speak of angels on a university campus...
strengths: Exceptional clarity and lack of religious clichés.
Nuanced description of human psychology and institutional power.
High degree of intellectual honesty regarding the 'awkwardness' of the text.
improvement_points: The term 'newness' is used frequently and could be more precisely defined.
The transition between the 'university campus' context and the 'angel' narrative could be even more tightly woven.
Some repetition of 'what a difference a week makes' risks becoming a rhetorical crutch.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Religious jargon is almost entirely absent; theological concepts are 'translated' into phenomenological and political language.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon possesses a distinct cadence, characterized by the repetitive refrain 'What a difference a week makes!' which acts as a rhythmic anchor. There is a skillful use of parallelism (e.g., 'perfect strength in weakness, perfect authority in gentleness...') that creates a liturgical 'flow.' The preacher uses staccato sentences to create tension and longer, more flowing sentences for theological reflection. The rhythm mimics the 'movement' of the story—from the stillness of Bethlehem to the frantic flight to Egypt. It is clearly written for the ear, with a natural oral 'breath' that allows for pauses and emphasis, particularly in the sections addressing the 'unequal conflict.'
quotes: The wise men depart, the angels vanish, Herod has business to conduct.
Perfect strength in weakness, perfect authority in gentleness, perfect sovereignty in grace.
Not always visible, not always triumphant, but at work in the midst of Herod’s insanity, and beyond.
strengths: Effective use of a rhetorical refrain to structure the oral event.
Strong variation in sentence length to guide the listener's attention.
Poetic quality in the descriptions of the 'vulnerable Jesus'.
improvement_points: The middle section on the 'baby' becomes slightly more didactic and loses some of the initial rhythmic drive.
Could utilize more alliteration or assonance to heighten the poetic impact of the conclusion.
The transition to the Isaiah quote feels slightly abrupt in the rhythmic flow.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Strongly oral language; the text feels like a transcript of a living performance rather than an essay.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The language is characterized by a 'sober beauty' that avoids sentimentality in favor of intellectual and rhetorical precision. It excels in 'reframing' biblical characters—moving them from static crèche figures to dynamic actors in a political drama. The imagery is sharp and contrasting, effectively using the 'innocence' of Christmas as a foil for the 'brutality' of the following week. The musicality is driven by a strong rhythmic refrain and balanced parallelism, making it highly effective for oral delivery in an academic or liturgical setting.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a sophisticated 'Homiletical Plot.' It begins by upsetting the equilibrium of the 'innocent' Christmas story, immediately introducing the tension of the 'long week.' The movement is not a static three-point sermon but a 'lingering' through a gallery of characters, each deepening the conflict. The turning point is the re-introduction of the angels in Section V, shifting the narrative from a hopeless 'unequal conflict' to a story of 'God's overplus.' The tension is sustained by refusing to resolve the 'slaughter of the innocents' too quickly, forcing the hearer to stand in the space between Herod's rage and the baby's vulnerability before offering the 'angelic' resolution.
quotes: It is that startling, drastic change in the characters that I want you to focus on...
The music in the background has taken on a chill.
If our story had had only Herod and Jesus in it, Herod would have won... What changes all that is that 'an angel of the Lord appeared.'
strengths: Excellent use of 'upsetting the equilibrium' at the start.
The structure follows the movement of the biblical text (Matthew 2) while maintaining its own thematic arc.
The conclusion returns to the 'university' context, closing the loop of the journey.
improvement_points: The transition between Section III and IV feels a bit like a pause in the movement; could be more fluid.
The 'bet your life' metaphor in Section IV is powerful but could be more integrated into the narrative flow.
Ensure the 'middle' doesn't feel like a list of characters but a continuous progression.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey that moves from 'innocence' through 'brutality' to 'resilient hope'.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is a prime example of Cilliers' 'reframing.' The preacher takes the 'strangeness' of the flight to Egypt and the slaughter of the innocents and frames it as a critique of modern 'socio-political, military, economic' forms of evil. The context of the 'university campus' is brilliantly integrated not as a mere backdrop, but as a character in itself—representing the 'Herodian' desire for control and 'quantifying analysis.' The synthesis is organic; the biblical text is not a springboard but the lens through which the 'status quo' of the hearers is interrogated. It respects the 'then' of the text while making the 'now' feel equally urgent.
quotes: The Bible brings us cold faced to the power of evil that takes socio-political, military, economic form.
In our tired, frightened status quo, in our lives of privilege and preference, Jesus scares us as much as he threatens Herod.
Indeed, the university is where we gather in celebration of our awesome control...
strengths: Masterful 'reframing' of the university setting in light of the gospel.
Honors the 'cruel' parts of the lectionary that are often skipped.
The application flows naturally from the character studies.
improvement_points: Could provide one more concrete contemporary example of 'Herodian' rage to sharpen the context.
The 'Egypt' metaphor could be more deeply explored as a contemporary space of safety or exile.
Balance the critique of the university with a moment of 'grace' for the academic task itself.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: The sermon offers a radical new frame, viewing the 'post-Christmas' week as a microcosm of the struggle between Empire and Kingdom.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: The sermon functions as an 'open work of art' by inviting the hearer to 'linger' and 'decide.' It does not offer a 'cheap' happy ending; the 'slaughter of the innocents' remains a painful reality ('not always triumphant'). By framing the choice as a 'bet' or a 'decision' in an 'unequal world,' it leaves room for the hearer's agency. However, the rhetorical force is quite strong, bordering on the 'coercive' in its moral clarity. While it acknowledges the mystery of the 'overplus of power,' it is very firm in its interpretation of who Herod and Jesus represent. It is polyvalent in its application but monovalent in its theological conviction.
quotes: In this conflict (and nowhere else) is where we must live and decide, and pick a winner.
Notice the odds, put your money down, and bet your life.
God’s powerful resolve is at work, not always visible, not always triumphant...
strengths: Ends with an invitation to a 'new beginning' rather than a set of rules.
Acknowledges the 'ambivalence of existence' by not explaining away the slaughter.
Treats the hearer as a mature partner capable of making a high-stakes 'bet'.
improvement_points: The 'we must' language in Section IV could be softened to allow more 'space' for the hearer's own struggle.
Could leave more 'unanswered' questions regarding the silence of God during the slaughter.
The conclusion is slightly 'sealed' by the definitive departure of the angel.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: Primarily open, though the prophetic tone creates a strong 'invitation' that feels almost like a demand.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetics are strong, driven by a narrative arc that moves from the 'innocence' of the crèche to the 'brutality' of the empire. The sermon excels in 'reframing' the biblical narrative for an academic context, turning the university's desire for control into a foil for the 'wild card' of God's grace. The structure is dynamic, lingering on characters to build tension before introducing the 'angelic' turning point. It avoids being a 'closed' system by acknowledging the ongoing reality of suffering and the 'vulnerability' of the gospel's power.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon is a powerful antidote to religious kitsch. It explicitly critiques the 'romantic' and 'innocent' tendencies of the church that prefer to skip over the 'cruel' verses of the lectionary. By refusing to resolve the tension between the 'slaughter of the innocents' and the 'safety of the baby' with easy platitudes, it achieves authentic aesthetic depth. There is no 'happy ending' that ignores the 'furious rage' of the world. The emotion is authentic—rooted in the 'cold-faced' reality of power and the 'resilient' nature of hope—rather than the 'sentiment' of a typical Christmas pageant.
examples_of_kitsch: The 'romantic' church that prefers to skip the cruel verses.
The 'maudlin and romantic' way angels are often discussed.
authentic_moments: The acknowledgment that 'Herod would have won' without the 'overplus' of God.
The description of God's power as 'not always visible, not always triumphant'.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Maintain this 'cold-faced' realism; it is what gives the eventual proclamation of grace its weight.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: Space for grace is opened precisely through the 'vulnerability' of the baby and the 'unavailability' of the angel. Cilliers' concept of 'reframing' is active here: the sermon moves reality from a 'quantifiable' Herodian frame to a 'grace-filled' frame where 'newness' is possible against all odds. It sustains the tension of the 'already/not yet'—the baby is safe, but the innocents are slaughtered. The 'overplus' of God is presented as a mystery that 'upsets all our equilibriums,' leaving space for the 'Holy' to happen outside of human control.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: The tension between Herod's massive power and Jesus' vulnerability is the heart of the sermon and is never cheaply resolved.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: Yes, the 'angel' is treated as a 'wild card'—unpredictable and beyond 'quantifying analysis'.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails, though it is a 'tough, hard, powerful' grace that demands a response.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: Continue to emphasize the 'unpredictability' of the angel to prevent the 'overplus' from becoming a new dogmatic formula.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically robust work that exemplifies the 'aesthetic turn' in homiletics. It moves beyond the 'vertical' proclamation of the Word to create a sensory and dramaturgical 'event' that reframes the hearer's reality. Its primary strength lies in its 'anti-kitsch' stance; it deliberately shatters the 'romantic' veneer of Christmas to reveal the 'cold-faced' struggle between Empire and the Kingdom of God. The poetics of language are precise and rhythmic, successfully translating biblical concepts into a modern, academic idiom without losing their 'strangeness.' The structure is narrative and dynamic, leading the hearer on a journey from 'innocence' through 'brutality' to a 'resilient hope' that is grounded in the 'overplus' of God's power. While the prophetic tone is strong and at times borders on the monovalent, it maintains enough 'openness' by acknowledging the ongoing presence of suffering and the 'vulnerability' of the divine actor. It is a sermon that 'shows' the transformation of the world through the lens of a 'long week,' creating a space where grace is not a sentimental feeling but a subversive, political reality.
strengths_top_3: Masterful reframing of the 'university context' as a site of Herodian control.
Vivid re-characterization of the angels from 'choir' to 'political actors'.
Strong anti-kitsch realism regarding the 'slaughter of the innocents'.
improvement_points_top_3: Reduce the slight over-reliance on the 'what a difference a week makes' refrain.
Soften the 'we must' language to increase the 'open work' quality for the hearer.
Incorporate more sensory 'showing' of the 'newness' promised in the conclusion.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Johan Cilliers (Reframing/Kitsch) and Paul Scott Wilson (Imagery/Four Pages).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Intellectually sophisticated hearers (students, faculty) who are skeptical of 'romantic' religion but hungry for a 'resilient' hope that takes the world's brutality seriously.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with an even more 'open' ending to see how it affects the 'bet your life' call.
Deepen the 'musicality' by using more poetic devices like alliteration in the 'grace' sections.
Try 'showing' the 'overplus of power' through a concrete contemporary story alongside the biblical one.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: The sermon is an excellent example of homiletic aesthetics that honors the 'sober beauty' of the Reformed tradition while embracing the 'aesthetic turn.' It avoids the pitfall of aestheticism by ensuring that the 'beauty' of the language serves the 'sharpness' of the prophetic message. By creating a 'space for grace' that is both vulnerable and resilient, the sermon allows the 'holy to happen' in the midst of a 'crazed' world. It is a highly effective performance of the gospel that challenges the hearer to 'see' reality through a new, angelic lens.
